demos.title: European Financial Promotion Guidance
demos.description: Validate social posts, landing pages, and emails against FCA Consumer Duty and social-media promotion rules; surface missing or unfair disclosures.
demos.extractionPrompt:
Extract atomic, testable rules from ONE policy document.
Keep each rule minimal.
Write for an LLM to apply it unambiguously.
Always include concise rationale and quotes.

Context additions (promotions):
- Scope this to FCA FG24/1 (social-media promotions) and FG22/5 (Consumer Duty).
- Target artifacts: short-form social posts, paid ads, landing pages, emails/SMS, in-app UI copy.
- Capture MUST/SHOULD strength, medium constraints (character limits), and prohibited/required phrases.
- For each rule, add: category {Disclosure|Prominence|Targeting|Fair-balance|Record-keeping}, medium applicability, severity {High|Med|Low}, testable threshold (e.g., warning ≥ claim prominence), and example pass/fail.
- Include precise section/para references and short quotes for traceability.
demos.consolidationPrompt:
Suggest deletes and merges to remove duplicates and generalize rules where appropriate.

Consolidation additions (promotions):
- Collapse medium-specific variants into one parent rule with medium flags.
- Prefer the strongest applicable obligation (MUST over SHOULD) while preserving all citations.
- Merge near-identical disclosure/prominence rules; standardize thresholds and wording.
- Remove rules that restate outcomes without actionable tests; keep those with measurable checks.
demos.validationPrompt:
Validate the provided marketing document against each FCA Consumer Duty and social-media promotion rule. For each rule, determine one of: pass, fail, n/a (rule not applicable), unknown (unsure — needs human review).

Context for validation:
- Focus on disclosure requirements, prominence of warnings, fair balance, and prohibited claims
- Consider medium-specific constraints (character limits, visual hierarchy)
- Look for required disclaimers, risk warnings, and clear/fair language
- Check targeting and accessibility requirements

Return a validation result for each rule with:
- id: the rule identifier
- result: one of ["pass", "fail", "n/a", "unknown"]
- reason: brief explanation citing specific parts of the document

demos.title: AI Model Governance Checklist
demos.description: Validate model cards, risk assessments, and vendor AI proposals against EU AI Act, PRA SS1/23, and NIST AI RMF expectations.
demos.extractionPrompt:
Extract atomic, testable rules from ONE policy document.
Keep each rule minimal.
Write for an LLM to apply it unambiguously.
Always include concise rationale and quotes.

Context additions (AI governance):
- Source types: EU AI Act (deployer obligations), PRA SS1/23 (model risk), NIST AI RMF 1.0.
- Target artifacts: model cards, validation reports, monitoring plans, change logs, vendor due-diligence responses.
- For each rule, include: control family {Data governance|Intended use|Transparency|Human oversight|Monitoring|Security|Privacy|Third-party}, lifecycle phase {Design|Train|Validate|Deploy|Monitor}, risk tier, severity, and explicit evidence expected (e.g., eval metrics, bias tests, rollback plan).
- Add clear pass/fail criteria (e.g., drift threshold defined and monitored ≥ monthly) with section/paragraph references.
demos.consolidationPrompt:
Suggest deletes and merges to remove duplicates and generalize rules where appropriate.

Consolidation additions (AI governance):
- Merge semantically equivalent controls across frameworks into a canonical statement with cross-refs (EU AI Act ↔ PRA SS1/23 ↔ NIST AI RMF).
- Prefer outcome-based wording plus a single measurable test; attach all source citations.
- Deduplicate documentation-only rules by folding into their parent control’s evidence list.
- Normalize severity and lifecycle tags; remove overlaps where monitoring or oversight duplicates exist.
demos.validationPrompt:
Validate the provided AI governance document against each extracted rule. For each rule, return one of: pass, fail, n/a (rule not applicable), unknown (unsure — needs human review).

Context for validation:
- Focus on data governance, intended use documentation, transparency requirements
- Check for human oversight controls, monitoring procedures, security measures
- Look for bias testing, performance metrics, rollback plans
- Verify lifecycle phase compliance and risk tier appropriateness

Return a validation result for each rule with:
- id: the rule identifier
- result: one of ["pass", "fail", "n/a", "unknown"]
- reason: brief explanation citing specific evidence or gaps in the document

demos.title: Operational Resilience (DORA) Readiness
demos.description: Validate incident runbooks, cloud SLAs, and resilience self-assessments against DORA and UK operational resilience expectations for ICT risk.
demos.extractionPrompt:
Extract atomic, testable rules from ONE policy document.
Keep each rule minimal.
Write for an LLM to apply it unambiguously.
Always include concise rationale and quotes.

Context additions (OpRes/DORA):
- Source types: EU DORA (ICT risk, incident reporting, TPRM), FCA PS21/3 & PRA SS1/21 (important business services, impact tolerances).
- Target artifacts: self-assessments, incident classification/runbooks, outsourcing/MSA clauses, BCP/DR test evidence, SLA/OLA documents.
- For each rule, add: domain {Important services|Impact tolerances|Incident mgmt|Testing|TPRM|Contracting}, evidence expected, regulator timeframe/thresholds, severity, and testable acceptance (e.g., regulator notification ≤ x hours with named role owner).
- Include clause/Article references and short quotes for audit traceability.
demos.consolidationPrompt:
Suggest deletes and merges to remove duplicates and generalize rules where appropriate.

Consolidation additions (OpRes/DORA):
- Merge UK OpRes and DORA rules where intent matches; keep time-bound thresholds as parameters.
- Collapse repeated contract-clause checks (audit/access/exit/data location) into a single reusable contract control with sub-checks.
- Remove narrative duplicates; keep the most measurable version and retain all citations.
- Standardize domain tags and notification/time thresholds across rules.
